summary: Dermatofibrosarcoma protuberans (DFSP) is a rare, locally aggressive malignant cutaneous soft-tissue sarcoma that develops in the connective tissue cells of the dermis. It is characterized by slow growth, a high rate of local recurrence, and a low metastatic potential. DFSP can resemble a bruise, birthmark, or pimple and is often found on the torso, but can occur anywhere on the body.
causes: Chromosomal translocation t(17;22) fusing COL1A1 and PDGF genes
risk_factors: Older age (most often arise in patients in their thirties, possibly due to diagnostic delay)
symptoms: Can resemble a bruise, birthmark, or pimple
diagnosis: Immunohistochemical stains (CD34, S-100 protein, factor XIIIa, estrogen and progesterone receptors)
Genetic and chromosomal testing (for t(17;22) translocation)
treatments: Surgical treatment (Mohs micrographic surgery, Wide local excision)
